title: Barclays Profit Rises in Fourth Quarter, Beating Estimates; Bank said it intends to start a share buyback program
text:
For all of 2021, Barclays earned £6.38 billion, up from £1.53 billion the previous year. The bank said it intends to start a share buyback program of up to £1 billion. It also said that inflationary pressure is likely to result in modestly higher costs in 2022.

Profit at Barclays's corporate and investment bank was £733 million during the fourth quarter, declining 37% from the previous quarter but higher than the same period last year. Profit at the bank's U.K. unit rose, reaching £420 million.

Shares in the bank climbed 2.6% in early trading Wednesday.

This is C.S. Venkatakrishnan's first earnings report since becoming chief executive after Jes Staley resigned following an investigation into his relationship with convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.

Mr. Venkatakrishnan has said he would continue Mr. Staley's strategy of maintaining a sizable trans-Atlantic investment bank alongside one of the U.K.'s leading retail and commercial banks. That combination proved resilient through much of the pandemic, with the investment bank booming on a flurry of deal making and trading.

The decline in investment banking activity mirrors the results of Wall Street's biggest banks, which saw their pandemic-era profits come back down to earth in the final quarter of last year. Both JPMorgan Chase & Co. and Citigroup Inc. reported double-digit declines in profit.

Banks have benefited from the volatility in markets, which boosted trading revenues. A surge of deal making also juiced profits. As major central banks signal tighter monetary policy ahead, this is expected to both boost and disadvantage banks.

The Bank of England's move to increase its policy interest rate twice since December to 0.5% has lifted the prospects of U.K. banks to charge more interest on loans, a key source of revenue. On the other hand, this is also expected to weigh on deal making, corporate borrowing and mortgage lending activity.
